div1.p: Kean discusses the “warfare” against the mosquito.

div1.head: Text of speech to be given upon the receipt of the Gorgas Medal, by Jefferson Randolph Kean, December 15, 1942
div1.opener:
For Col. Philip S. Hench-
What was in my mind to say, but was left unsaid- J. R. Kean-
THE GORGAS MEDAL. December 15, 1942
div1.p:
It is certainly a singular good fortune for me to be here today to
receive, before this distinguished company, a beautiful medal bearing
the name of an old and valued friend. An additional honor is that of
being bracketed with two such notable scientists as are Admiral Stitt
and General Russell. The engrossed citation which has been handed me by
Mr. Law pleased me no less, albeit I am somewhat embarrassed at the gen-
orosity of the ascriptions. Far be it from me to be critical of them
however, signed as they are by the President and the Secretary of the
Association of Military Surgeons of the United States of America.

The statement at the beginning of the citation that I was the first
to initiate warfare against the mosquito is one on which I desire to
say a few words. I asked my friend Colonel Hume why it was this, which
seemed most to interest the members of the press, though I considered
it of less importance than some of the other things mentioned. He said
that it seemed to have for the public more news value than matters of
organization or planning.

The method of attack on the mosquito was not invented, as has been
thought, for the Yellow Fever Campaign of 1901 in Cuba. It had been de-
vised and described years before by Dr. L. O. Howard who was for many
years the Chief of the Bureau of Entomology, Dept. of Agriculture. He
was an esteemed friend of Walter Reed and he and his assistant Dr.
Carroll went to Dr. Howard's laboratory to get points on mosquitoes be-
fore the Yellow Fever Board went to Cuba. Dr. Howard is still living,
though well along in the eighth decade and is a member of the Walter Reed
Memorial Association. It was from one of his publications that I had
learned some years before the Spanish War the use of kerosene sprayed
on the surface of deposits of water to kill the larvae of mosquitoes..
When I was stationed at Key West Barracks in 1895 I recall recommending
to the Mayor to use this method upon some pools just off the Military
Reservation and within the city limits which were breeding clouds of
mosquitoes. But the average Key Wester of those days was more philo-
sophical than progressive. He was inclined to accept flies, fleas and
mosquitoes as the expected and unavoidable accompaniments of mundane
existence, upon which it was useless to expend precious dollars and un-
welcome efforts. It was at this time that I first met our friend Admiral
Stitt, and also Walter Reed who came down on a scientific errand and
was my guest for a week.

May I now skip five years over the period of the Spanish War, one
of the consequences of which to me was to land me in Cuba with the Army
of Occupation. A year later we had a Yellow Fever epidemic. Major
Walter Reed was at Columbia Barracks with his famous Yellow Fever Board.
Soon Lazear had produced a couple of verified cases with his infected
mosquitoes, and their agency in transmitting malaria also had been re-
cently demonstrated by a British Army doctor named Ross. So it was no

great stroke of genius in me to think of Dr. Howard and kerosene and to
recommend to my good Chief General Fitzhugh Lee in October, and to
General Wood in December, the warfare against this enemy of man. Gen-
eral Lee I think did not believe a word of the theory, but he disliked
mosquitoes and liked me, so he promptly signed my circular of instruc-
tions to all commanding officers.

But the case was different with the men who had much experience
with this extraordinary disease and had seen one theory after another
disproved almost as soon as it was published. Dr. Osler in an address
to a graduating class of medical students quoted with approval the state-
ment of some old Greek philosopher that a judicious skepticism is an
important attribute of the scientific mind. Major Gorgas whose name
this medal appropriately bears, had long been looked up to by us all as
the Yellow Fever expert of the Army Medical Corps. He had been kept
stationed at Southern Military posts for years so as to be conveniently
on call. He and Reed were good friends and held each others opinions
in high respect. But he viewed Reed's experiments with Osler's scienti-
fic skepticism. I am not telling any tales out of school, for he has
left on record in an official report, written more than a year later,
after we had all left Cuba, his disbelief in the mosquito theory when
it was announced by Walter Reed at the Pan American Medical Congress
held in Havana, Cuba, Feb. 4, 1901. He said in this report “I myself
had seen the work, and was convinced that the mosquito could convey
yellow fever, but I was hardly prepared to believe that it was the only
way or even the ordinary way of conveying the disease.” * But General
Wood wanted it done and would find the money to do it and Gorgas was
quite willing to carry out loyalty and efficiently the wishes of his
Commanding General. Conviction came to him from the success of his own
work.

Looking back on the episode in its entirety, as we can do after a
lapse of more than 40 years, we can see that Gorgas lost nothing in
fame or in opportunity by his scientific skepticism. I, however have
gained something by the promptness of my conversion, of which the re-
searches of Dr. Philip S. Hench of the Mayo Clinic has dug up the doc-
umentary evidence, out of the limbo of forgotten records. I have ob-
tained a place, which I hardly deserve, in Cornwell's now famous paint-
ing of the Conquerors of Yellow Fever and mention in this much valued
citation. I wish to thank Mr. Law and Mr. Kellogg for the medal and
for the very acceptable Christmas gift which comes with it.
* Final Report as Chief Sanitary Officer of Habana dated July 12, 1902
